request.text: What is the voltage on R8?

solution: *** Solution by TINA assisted by AI ***
At first we calculate the total resistance between the generator nodes (VS1)
R12 and R11 connected in parallel so Rc=R12*R11/(R12+R11)=1Ohm
Rc and R10 connected in series so Rb=Rc+R10=2Ohm
R9 and R8 connected in parallel so Rh=R9*R8/(R9+R8)=1Ohm
Rh and R7 connected in series so Rg=Rh+R7=2Ohm
R4 and R5 connected in series so Rk=R4+R5=2Ohm
R2 and R1 connected in parallel so Rn=R2*R1/(R2+R1)=1Ohm
Rn and R3 connected in series so Rm=Rn+R3=2Ohm
Rk and Rm connected in parallel so Rj=Rk*Rm/(Rk+Rm)=1Ohm
Rg and Rj connected in series so Rf=Rg+Rj=3Ohm
Rf and R6 connected in series so Re=Rf+R6=4Ohm
Rb and Re connected in parallel so Ra=Rb*Re/(Rb+Re)=1.33Ohm
The total resistance is Ra = 1.33Ohm
Now we calculate the voltage on R8
We know that the voltage between VS1 nodes is 5V.
(1) The components Rb,Re connected in parallel. The voltage on Re is 5V because the voltage on Ra is 5V
(2) The components Rf,R6 connected in series.
(2) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 5V.
(2) Rf is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rf is Rf/Re*5V = 3.75V.
(3) The components Rg,Rj connected in series.
(3) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 3.75V.
(3) Rg is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rg is Rg/Rf*3.75V = 2.5V.
(4) The components Rh,R7 connected in series.
(4) The voltage between this components starting and ending node is 2.5V.
(4) Rh is in the voltage divider so the voltage on Rh is Rh/Rg*2.5V = 1.25V.
(5) The components R9,R8 connected in parallel. The voltage on R8 is 1.25V because the voltage on Rh is 1.25V
*** Passed ***: expected: 1.25, got: 1.25
